lightning is bitcoin: to net transactions, increase transaction capacity, make faster immediately final payments, lower fees and make new micropayment use cases possible. it is a like a write-back transaction cache above the mainchain. replacement payments shadow the writes.

during which dollar cost averaging historically was better than buying all of your bitcoin allocation on day1. some kind of moderate mix, overlaid with what you think is probably reasonable. eg buy some nowish if you're starting, but have some money to buy more to lower average.

going all-in on day1 may not be best as it depends on market conditions, in a general up market period all in earlier looks better. but bitcoin is both short term and mid term volatile, direction is not that predictable. dont forget bitcoin has had 18month sideways/down periods.

i'm looking at it as risk lowered in USD terms, as a dollar allocation. historically it has been better to buy bitcoin all-in and hold. so if random buying being average 50% in bitcoin is closer to buy/hold it will win vs dip buying but be more bitcoin than dollar exposed.

you're not necessarily trying to predict price movements, just benefit from them. bitcoin goes up, bitcoin goes down. say you modelled that as random walk. predicting price movements would be buying the oversold news ("china bans bitcoin").

I am sure historically it's a losing strategy vs going all in bitcoin. for me it's a dollar allocation (i'm already heavily bitcoin weighted... keeping some cash, and this is a way to make bitcoin related gains and keep the profit in BTC, with a USD allocation).
